Award.AwardTitle: RUI: Acid and Base Stress in Escherichia coli

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
INTELLECTUAL MERIT:
Acid and base, as measured by pH, are important to promote and/or control bacterial growth and survival in all environments, from soil and water to the human skin and intestine. Microbes form acids during food production, and acids are important food preservatives. Acid and base influence microbial production of biofuels and pharmaceuticals. Acid and base production change the external environment of growing bacteria but mechanisms of transport and metabolism help bacterial cells maintain near-constant pH inside, under acid or base stress from outside. Most of what is currently understood on bacterial adaptation to changes in the external environment applies to aerated cultures grown in liquid medium under laboratory conditions. This research will identify how the bacterium Escherichia coli responds to acid stress and base stress under conditions found in natural environments, such as low oxygen and biofilms. Undergraduate researchers will employ fluorescence microscopy and laboratory evolution to address: (1) How do bacterial cells regulate pH as they divide and undergo polar aging? (2) How does pH stress cause oxidation stress (3) How do bacteria evolve under acid stress to grow at lower pH than the ancestral strain The answers to these questions will help the fermentation industry devise improved food preservatives and processes for biotechnology.

BROADER IMPACTS:
The project will contribute to the nation's human resources by continuing a productive research program run by undergraduates. Each year, 10 first-year student researchers will be recruited from the Kenyon College STEM programs and science classes, as well as 2 high school students. Students will learn fundamental techniques of microbiological research while working with more advanced peers in BIOL 385 Research in Biology and BIOL 497 Senior Honors. They will write their own mini-proposals, design and conduct the experiments, and draft the manuscript for publication. Many undergraduates attracted to work on this project decide to pursue careers in science. Students will also serve as judges for the high-school science fair, and provide materials and demonstrations for members of an economically underserved community.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Our research focused on how bacteria survive extreme stress from acids and bases. For example, how do bacteria survive stomach acid and pancreatic base secretions? How do acid-adapted bacteria shift gears to grow in the intestine? And what happens to bacteria treated with organic acids such as aspirin?

Teams of undergraduate researchers investigated these questions by fluorescence microscopy and by experimental evolution of the model organism Escherichia coli. For each project, a team leader organized students to conduct daily dilutions and growth curves of bacterial mutant strains. Figure 1 shows undergraduates Karina Kunka and Jessie Griffith performing culture dilutions. Each growth assay must to be replicated by two different members of the group—a signature requirement for all our publications. In all, 38 undergraduates and high school students participated in this project. Three publications in leading journals included 17 undergraduates and 2 post-bac coauthors. Eight graduates went on to PhD or post-bac programs, and four are now planning to apply.

A surprising effect of acid stress we discovered was asymmetric cell growth by “half-cell aging.” As each bacterial cell divides, each daughter cell inherits an old cell pole and a new cell pole formed from the midpoint. For each subsequent generation, a lineage of cells inherits the original old cell pole, as well as a new pole. In acid, this half-aging detracts from cell growth, and has implications for bacterial drug resistance.

Stronger acid, near the growth limit (pH 4.6) affects bacteria as they leave the stomach to grow in the intestine. We found that bacteria cultured at pH 4.6 for 2,000 generations show specific mutant alleles that are favored by natural selection. Surprisingly, the mutations delete traits that help the bacteria survive short-term acid, such as breakdown of amino acids to release alkaline amines. These short-term responses detract from fitness in acid over long-term generations. Other acid-selected mutations in RNA polymerase cause global reregulation of many genes in ways that increase acid fitness.

Another student team investigated bacterial evolution in the presence of the organic acid benzoate, a metabolic product of aspirin. Unexpectedly, they found that selection for benzoate tolerance concurrently selects for loss of resistance to antibiotics such as tetracycline and chloramphenicol. A comparable tradeoff occurs for tolerance to salicylate—the main active product of aspirin in the human body. Figure 2 shows undergraduate Erick Ditmars presenting this research at the American Society for Microbiology General Meeting. We are now following up this discovery by testing whether salicylate has similar effects on microbial communities of the mouse intestine. Figure 3 shows undergraduate Adama Berndt reporting preliminary results of salicylate effects on the gut microbiome.
